p.s: To get a better view of the opinions and line of thought of certain characters, it is important to take a deeper look into the course of the conversation, such a individual character evaluation.
The very beginning of the excerpt shows Abe's attitude towards his troubles with the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation.
As he laughed (cf. l. 4), he doesn't really takes seriously, that he could get deported soon.
Even though he is afraid of his mother (cf. l. 16) and comes to Amir for help, he doesn't really listen to his advices and seems like he got it all under control (cf. l. 8, l. 10-11).
By questioning Amir all the time (cf. l. 23, l. 28, l. 30) he wants to seem superior and is probably still defiant because of what happened to Emily.
He doesn't want Amir to tell or teach him anything any longer, which also gets emphasized by Abe cutting off Amir (cf. l. 30).
His defiance gets stressed by him simply saying that he is not on the same side as the authorities even though Amir strongly recommends him to be so (cf. ll. 31-36).
Using an anaphora of maybe (cf. ll. 40-41) Abe's doubts about living in the US become clear.
He seems to feel unfitting and not comfortable.
By talking about how both of their fathers wanted to make a better life for themselves and their families (ll. 42-43).
Amir tries to go onto a more personal level and bond with Amir.
However the opposite happens and Abe bursts out (A better life?, l. 44).
Full of anger, Abe starts making accusations and shouts at his uncle (cf. l. 46, l. 48).
By talking about Emily in a quiet, intense (cf. l. 50) way, he hits Amir in a sensitive spot.
AmirsAmir's response I don't know (l. 52), also shows how he is ashamed for his unexplainable behaviour.
Amir realizes his situation in the conversation and for that wants to restore his pride by reminding Abe to be respectful (cf. l. 55).
It becomes clear that Abe has had a personality change as he changed his name back (cf. l. 59) and now wears a kufi in public (cf. l. 60), which is a Muslim skullcap.
Abe seems to no longer be afraid to show his Muslim background in public.
For that, he becomes the opposite of Amir who tries to hide his identity and hates his cultural and religious background.
Abe talks about how he used to look up to Amir but now cannot stand his pessimistic views any longer (cf. ll. 64-66).
It becomes clear how much the problems they've faced pressured and traumatized Abe (You have no idea what it did to me!, l. 68).
AmirsAmir's behaviour has not only damaged himself and his marriage, but also his social surrounding.
By talking about the destiny (l. 73) to conquer the world (l. 70) one realizes that Abe has not only had a change of mind, but now is convinced of more extreme and even radical things.
This excerpt shows the evolution of the relationship between Abe and Amir throughout the play.

Abe used to look up to Amir and trust him (even more than his own mother, (cf. l. 16)) but now finds himself disgusted with his uncle (cf. l. 63), as he has been shaming his background and through that damaged everything around him.
What is noticable is that Abe talks way more than Amir does in this excerpt.
Amir seems to let Abe say everything he wants as he cannot say a word to defend himself and for that realizes his mistakes.
It becomes quite obvious how Abe changed throughout the play.
Being a not so relevant character in the beginning, he is a testament for the impact of discrimination on young people and how that can even get to radicalisation.
Being like a mirror to Amir and enumerating all the things he has done wrong, he is leaving Amir in disgrace.
